title-group.article-title: Adaptative Progressive Damage Modeling for Large-scale Composite Structures

article-meta.aff: Laboratory of Technology and Strength of Materials, Department of Mechanical Engineering and Aeronautics, University of Patras, 26500 Rion, Greece

abstract.p: Progressive damage modeling (PDM) is a well-established methodology for the prediction of damage initiation and evolution in composite structures. However, as conventional PDM methodology involves a large post-processing procedure, it is impractical for application in large-scale structures due to the high computational cost it requires. In this study, the local character of nonlinearity, due to the scale of the damage topology compared to the size of the entire structure, is exploited to propose proper modifications in the ‘classical’ PDM methodology. Specifically, the sub-modeling technique principles are combined and integrated in the PDM methodology and the appropriate modifications required are discussed. Furthermore, two damage prediction indices, which are related to the criticality of damage state at specific sub-areas (material layers) of the structure are introduced, in order to achieve significant reductions of the required computational time. Both the improvements make the application of PDM in large-scale composite structures practically feasible; this is demonstrated in the case of a generic composite shear joint whose numerical model comprises over a million degrees of freedom.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In large-scale structures, material damage initiation and propagation is usually a local phenomenon that initiates locally mainly in areas of pre-existing material defects, manufacturing imperfections, high-stress fields, and accidental/service or inefficiently maintained damage. These areas are considered as hot spots of the structure. Consequently, the material nonlinearity introduced in the structural stress analysis, due to material damage, can also be considered to have local character, at least up to the point when these local damages start interacting between each other or have sufficiently grown up to the structure’s scale.

The methodology of progressive damage modeling (PDM) has been widely applied in the prediction of damage development in various types of composite structures (e.g., Gotsis et al., 1998; Kermanidis et al., 2000; Tserpes et al., 2001, 2002, 2004; Labeas et al., 2008; Tay et al., 2008; Haj-Ali, 2009; Ju et al., 2009; Zhang and Wang, 2010). However, the application of PDM in large-scale structures, which require multi-million degrees of freedom (DOF) numerical models for their stress analysis, has specific significant problems. The first problem arises in the pre-processing part of the procedure and it is due to the extremely high number of DOFs in the finite element (FE) models, which results in solution times that are considerably increased compared to regular structures. The second problem, which aggregates to the first, arises in the post-processing part and it is due to the large number of iterations required from the PDM methodology routine to simulate the damage development and predict the nonlinear behavior that lead to exceptionally large computational times. The third drawback is that the steps of the PDM related with the application of damage criteria and material degradation rules are exceptionally time-consuming, since they are executed in exterior sub-routines, the integration of which is not possible in the commercial FE codes. For these reasons, there is no published work so far, demonstrating the application of PDM methodology to a real large-scale structural problem.

In this study, an attempt to overcome the problems associated to the applicability of PDM methodology in large-scale structures is performed, by exploiting the local character of nonlinearity due to damage initiation and development, in order to simulate the damage evolution in large-scale composite structures. For this purpose, proper modifications at the PDM methodology procedure are proposed. More specifically, the sub-modeling technique principles are combined and integrated in the PDM methodology, such that the stress-analysis step of the PDM methodology is performed significantly faster. Furthermore, two damage prediction indices, which are capable of predicting the criticality of damage state at the material, are introduced in order to achieve significant reduction of the required computational time, by excluding noncritical areas from the application of the failure analysis modules of the PDM method. Both improvements make the application of PDM in large-scale composite structures practically feasible; this is demonstrated in the case of a generic composite shear joint whose model comprises a million DOF.

sec.title: PDM OVERVIEW
sec.p:
An overview of the basic steps of a typical analysis methodology based on the principles of PDM is presented in Figure 1. PDM is essentially based on an iterative methodology comprising three main modules. The first module is the development and solution of a validated computational model of the structure for the determination of stresses and strains at an appropriate scale level for the subsequent analysis steps. The operational load is divided into an appropriate number of load steps. Each load step is engaging a series of numerical calculations assuming that no changes in the material stress–strain behavior will take place within one step. Figure 1.
Overview of a typical PDM methodology.

The second module of the methodology deals with the prediction of localized failure based on the various failure theories. In the macro-mechanics level, computed lamina stresses/strains are compared to material allowable or their combination in order to predict failure formation and type. Hashin failure criteria (Hashin and Rotem, 1973; Hashin, 1980), as modified by Shokrieh and Lessard (2000), are suitable for use in PDM models, since they distinguish between different failure modes, show a satisfactory accuracy and correlate very well with experimental results. Consequently, they have been also used in the modified PDM applications presented herein.

The mathematical forms of Hashin’s criteria are presented in Table 1, where σij are the calculated lamina stress components in the (ij) direction and the denominators the ultimate strengths in the corresponding direction. The failure modes considered are matrix tensile and compressive cracking, fiber tensile and compressive failure, fiber–matrix shear-out, and delamination in tension and compression. Table 1.

The third basic module, which completes the PDM methodology, concerns the response of the damaged material volumes due to the progressive damage evolution within the structure. Degrading material property is the most usual way to fit the failed structure response to that observed in the experiments. Due to the reduction in material mechanical properties, the stiffness of the structure changes locally, therefore, the structure equilibrium at the current load step should be re-established, taking into account the modified material properties of the ‘failed’ material volumes. As this stress redistribution may lead to additional material failures, the whole analysis should be repeated until no failures are detected. Only then, the load may be further increased to the next loading level and the previously described main modules of PDM method re-executed iteratively, until catastrophic failure of the structure is detected. The intermediate results of the PDM approach comprise the history of failure mode evolution within the structure as well as ultimate load at final failure.

In this study, the sudden material property degradation rules presented in Table 2 have been applied to represent the response of the damaged material volumes. The sudden material property degradation rule of Table 2 is a mixed set, comprising the rules of Tan (1991), as they were extended by Camanho and Matthews (1999) for matrix tensile and compressive cracking and for fiber tensile and compressive failure. The degradation in Poisson’s ratio is restricted by the relationships between the engineering properties of the anisotropic materials (Jones, 1999). To allow practical application of the degradation rules, the degraded material properties are assumed to have a very small value instead of zero, in order to avoid numerical problems in the FE solution. sec.title: DESCRIPTION OF SPECIFIC PROBLEMS ARISING FROM PDM APPLICATION IN LARGE-SCALE STRUCTURES
sec.p:
PDM methodology is well-established and has been successfully applied for the prediction of damage initiation and evolution of structures made of composite materials (e.g., Gotsis et al., 1998; Kermanidis et al., 2000; Tserpes et al., 2001, 2002, 2004; Labeas et al., 2008; Haj-Ali, 2009; Ju et al., 2009; Zhang and Wang, 2010). However, its application, according to authors’ best knowledge, has been limited at rather small-scale structures, including simple geometry specimens, as well as more complicated bolted and bonded joints. However, the ‘classic’ PDM methodology has not been applied so far in large-scale structures due to specific problems that can be summarized as:
There is a large-scale difference between the length scale of the structure and the scale of the area where composite material damage initiates and evolutes; specifically, the dimensions of the entire structure are by orders of magnitude higher compared to a damaged volume, which extends to an area of some square millimeters and thickness equal to a layer thickness usually being 0.125 mm. This difference generates a difficulty in the accurate calculation of the stresses/strains at these small areas of damage evolution. Specifically, the analysis model of these areas should be three-dimensional, i.e., modeling the laminate in layer-by-layer basis in order to accurately capture interlaminar failures, as well as, the FE size of these critical areas should be extremely small; both requirements lead to numerical models comprising extremely large number of elements and DOF, taking into account the large size of the structure. The computational needs for the solution of such models are so high that the solution becomes many times more difficult compared to the usual computational analyses of lower length-scale structures, which are already published in the literature (Gotsis et al., 1998; Kermanidis et al., 2000; Tserpes et al., 2001, 2002, 2004; Labeas et al., 2008; Haj-Ali, 2009; Ju et al. 2009; Zhang and Wang, 2010).
Numerous iterations of the PDM methodology routines are required as the methodology requires that the external load is applied in sufficiently small load steps, in order to sufficiently simulate the nonlinear behavior when material failure occurs. In addition, when damage evolutes within a load step, further iterations are required to satisfy static equilibrium. The above characteristics, coupled with the fact that in a large-scale structure, there are many different critical sites that may develop sequentially or simultaneously, lead to the need for the solution of an extremely large number of numerical models of the structure.
Finally, in the conventional PDM methodology, the modules that concern the failure analysis and the material property degradation are applied in each and every layer/element of the composite material, making the respective processes exceptionally time-consuming. Moreover, since the above processes are executed in external sub-routines of the FE code, the respective computational time becomes extremely long, if not prohibitive, in cases of large-scale structural analysis.

sec.title: PDM METHODOLOGY MODIFICATIONS
sec.p:
In this study, certain modifications are proposed in the conventional PDM methodology, so that its application for the analysis of large-scale structures becomes feasible and effective. The three proposed modifications aiming to overcome the problems of classic PDM methodology, as they have been discussed in the previous section, consist in:
The first modification aims to the reduction of computational time required by the module of stress analysis. This is achieved by employing the FE sub-modeling technique. This modification is utilized by applying the ‘global–local’ principles in the stress analysis. Initially, a rough FE model is developed for the entire large-scale structure. From the global model, the critical areas (hot spots) of the structure are identified and for them only the FE sub-modeling principle is applied by developing detailed numerical models (sub-models). By means of these detailed numerical models, accurate predictions of the stress fields, damage analysis, and material property degradation are performed only for the hot-spot areas of the model and not for the entire structure, as in the case of the conventional PDM.
The second modification aims in the reduction of computational time required by the failure analysis and material property degradation modules of the PDM methodology. This is achieved by the introduction of a damage index referred to as ‘layer/element damage’ index, which assesses the probability of damage initiation within a material layer/element of a sub-model and is predicted according to the applied failure criteria. When this index is below a specific critical value in a load step, the failure analysis and property degradation modules are omitted for the specific layer/element of the composite material.
The third modification aims at a further reduction of computational time required for stress analysis, failure analysis, and material property degradation modules of the PDM method. This is achieved by the introduction of a damage index referred to as ‘sub-area damage’ index for each one of the sub-models described above. This index characterizes the severity of each sub-model with respect to damage initiation and it is used by the same logic as the previous index, in order to omit the stress analysis module and apparently the failure analysis and material property degradation modules of noncritical sub-areas of the structures, thus reducing the calculation cost of PDM application significantly.

The incorporation of the above modifications in the conventional PDM methodology is presented in the following paragraphs. Consequently, the modified PDM methodology is applied in the case of a large-scale generic composite shear joint, the simulation of which requires a million DOF FE model.

sec.title: Incorporation of Global–Local Principles and Sub-Modeling Technique in the PDM Methodology
sec.p:
Sub-modeling technique is often used in the FE analysis in order to get more accurate stress/strain results in regions of high-stress concentrations. This is achieved by initially creating a global coarse FE model, along with a separate finely meshed numerical model (sub-model) for the sub-areas of interest. In Figure 2, a coarse FE model of a panel with bolt holes and a finely meshed FE model of a bolt-hole sub-area are shown. The boundary of this sub-region, which is a line in the case of a two-dimensional model or a surface in the case of a three-dimensional model, is called cut-boundary. The sub-model is solved by applying at the cut-boundary the generalized displacements that have been calculated using the global model. To perform this application, a linear interpolation of the displacements calculated by the global rough model on the cut-boundary nodes locations of the local dense model is required, as the discretization of global and local FE models do not match. Figure 2.
Application of the sub-modeling technique in the case of bolt-hole panel (a) global model and (b) local sub-model.

In this study, the sub-modeling principles are incorporated in the stress-analysis module of large-scale composite structures for the detailed modeling of areas that are critical for the initiation and development of damage. Apparently, the damage analysis and material property degradation modules are executed only for the critical sub-areas of the structure that are sub-modeled, limiting, thus, the computation cost.

By the above modification, increased though-the-thickness discretization density can be utilized, resulting to more accurate calculation of interlaminar normal and shear stresses, which is essential for delamination initiation and evolution prediction in composite structures. In addition, application of the sub-modeling technique enables a more precise prediction of damage patterns, arising from the denser discretization of the sub-model critical areas; this would lead to multi-million DOF FE models under the conventional PDM, the solution of which would be very difficult or even impossible.

The concept of the FE sub-modeling technique is schematically presented in Figure 3, for the case of the bolt-hole problem presented in Figure 2. The results of the global FE rough model (Figure 3(a)) show that this sub-area (Figure 3(b)) is a hot-spot area and requires sub-modeling and refinement. The sub-area model, as refined with much denser discretization (i.e. from 6 elements through-the-thickness to 18 elements), is shown in Figure 3(c). This sub-model is solved and the modules of failure analysis and material property degradation are executed. An example of a typical topology of layers/elements exhibiting failure is illustrated in Figure 3(d). The values of the predicted degraded material properties are stored in order to be used as initial conditions at the sub-model in the following iteration of the PDM application (Figure 3(g)) obtained after the subsequent stress and failure analysis results in an updated failure pattern (Figure 3(h)). Figure 3.
FE sub-modeling technique concept.

At this stage, and prior to the execution of the subsequent steps of the iterative methodology, degraded material properties that have been defined for the failed layers/elements of the finely meshed sub-model have to be properly assigned to the associated elements of the global coarse model (Figure 3(e) and (f)). In order to achieve this, for each set of sub-model layers/elements related to an element of the global model, an appropriate homogenization process of the element’s material properties has to be applied. In the case that both global model and sub-model comprise solid FEs, the homogenized material properties of the global model elements are calculated as the mean value of the respective material properties of the sub-model elements. All the other homogenized material properties are calculated accordingly.

In the special case that the global rough model comprises shell FEs, while the sub-model consists of solid FEs, the homogenized material properties of the global model shell elements, i.e. the stiffness matrices [A], [B], and [D], according to the classical laminate theory, may be calculated by the following relationships: (2) (3) (4) where Aij, Bij, and Dij are the components of the respective stiffness matrices, Nply the total number of layers of the laminate, (Qij)k the stiffness of layer k in the ij plane, and zk the through-the-thickness distance of the k-layer from the laminate mid-plane. Similar and alternative approaches to damage homogenization may be found in the papers of Jain and Ghosh (2009), Louhghalam and Arwade (2010), and Lubineau (2010).

It should be mentioned here, that due to the material property reductions, the stiffness of the structure changes locally; therefore, the current stress solution of the global computational model does not represent an equilibrium state any more. The structure equilibrium at the current load step is established again, by solving the global model taking into account the modified material properties of the ‘failed’ material volumes, until no additional failures are detected at the specific load step. Only then the load may be further increased to the next loading level. The previously described modules of PDM method are re-executed iteratively, until catastrophic failure of the structure is detected.

sec.title: Layer/Element Damage Index
sec.p: In order to further reduce the computational cost of the PDM methodology, especially for the cases of its application in large-scale structures, a damage index is introduced, targeting the limitation of the time-consuming failure analysis checks. This index, hereafter referred to as the ‘LED’ index, is defined for each layer/element of a sub-model and for each failure mode and it is related to the probability of failure of this layer/element according to the applied failure criteria. LED index is calculated at every PDM iteration and for each layer/element. It indicates how far or close this element lies with respect to the initiation of a specific type of failure.

The LED indices are defined at the initial iteration/load step of the PDM application to be equal to the respective failure criteria values, as evaluated by the relationships of Table 1. For the LED indices, the symbol delem-type-1 is used. At the symbol, subscript elem designates the layer/element number that is examined, type denotes the failure type under consideration, and l indicates that the LED index refers to the first load step of the PDM application.

For the subsequent load steps, the values of LED indices are calculated by making the assumption that local stress components, developed at the layer/element under consideration, is a function of the external applied loads only and are not affected by the development of failures at other layers/elements of the numerical model. Thus, based on the definition of the LED indices LED index delem-type-s at load step s can be estimated as the product of the respective LED index at the first load step to a function of the ratio of the current load Ps to the initial load P1. At every load step, whether the failure analysis at a layer/element of the numerical model will be executed or not, it is decided by the LED indices, in the sense that the failure analysis is omitted for all layers/elements of which LED indices are lower than a critical value dcr. sec.title: Sub-Area Damage Index
sec.p: The second damage index introduced in the conventional PDM methodology aims at the limitation of the sub-areas for which the sub-modeling analysis and the subsequent failure analysis and material property degradation modules are executed. This index is called ‘sub-area damage’ (SAD) index and it is denoted by D. It is defined for each sub-area of the numerical model and it indicates the probability of damage initiation within this sub-area. A SAD index is calculated, for each sub-area and failure mode, as the maximum of the respective LED indices of the layers/elements of the respective sub-model at each PDM load step. When SAD indices of a sub-area are below a threshold Dcr, the application of stress analysis (utilizing sub-modeling technique), failure analysis, and material property degradation modules is omitted for the specific sub-area.

sec.title: APPLICATION OF PDM METHODOLOGY IN THE CASE OF A GENERIC SHEAR JOINT
sec.p:
The proposed modified PDM methodology has been applied on a large-scale use-case, a complex and multi-material joint connecting three panels (Figure 5), formerly proposed by EADS as a use-case representative of an aircraft structural joint, in the frame of the European research project MUSCA (MUltiSCAle Analysis of large aerostructures, EU FP6 Project, 2005). The joint consists of two composite panels (designated panels 1–2) assembled together by fittings and fasteners, submitted to shear loading. Figure 5.
Schematic representation of the generic shear joint.

Panel 1 has been made from HS material, with a total thickness of about 12 mm, 50 plies, and an orientated lay-up (approximately 50% of 0° plies, 20% of 45° plies, 20% of −45° plies, and 10% of 90° plies). The mechanical properties for material HS are Ε1 = 150 GPa, E2 = 8.5 GPa, G12 = 4 GPa, and ν12 = 0.35. Panel 2 has been made of IM material, with a total thickness of about 11 mm, and a lay-up with similar orientation. The mechanical properties for the IM material are: Ε1 = 130 GPa, E2 = 8.5 GPa, G12 = 4 GPa, and ν12 = 0.35.

The application of the conventional PDM methodology on the specific structure is prohibitive since it would involve the development of an extremely large FE model, which should be capable to simulate the global behavior of the joint and at the same time provide accurate information about the detailed stress fields areas around the bolt holes; for the case of a bolted joint they represent the hot spots of the structure due to the large loads transferred from the bolts to the panels. On the other hand, as it will be shown further down, damage evolution at the composite material cannot be neglected, due to its major effect on the load transfer from the bolts to the composite panels.

Therefore, the modified PDM methodology is necessary to be applied for the damage evolution analysis in the generic shear joint. The flowchart of the application of the modified PDM methodology in this case is presented in Figure 6. Generally, the same procedure can be applied for the damage evolution analysis of any large-scale structural problem. The basic steps of the application of the modified PDM method in the case of the generic shear joint are described in the following sections. Figure 6.
Flowchart of the modified PDM methodology application.

sec.title: Global FE Model Development and Solution
sec.p:
For the implementation of the modified PDM methodology, the global FE model of the structure has been initially developed using the ANSYS FE code. All parts of the structure have been represented using the SOLID185 element, while CONTA173 and TARGE170 elements have been utilized for the simulation of contact between the structural parts. The global FE mesh of the generic shear joint including the gripping frames is shown in Figure 7. It consists of 1,533,198 nodes and 2,310,862 elements of which 496,896 are the contact elements. Figure 7.
Global FE mesh of generic shear joint and frame tooling.

Nonlinear analysis has been applied for the solution of the FE model of the generic shear joint due to the existence of contact elements that introduce geometric nonlinearity. The external load is applied at two mandrels placed diagonally at the frames. The maximum load is 1200 kN applied in load steps of 12 kN. Global FE model development and solution have been performed at a HP xw9400 workstation with two dual-core Opteron processors and 16Gbyte of RAM. Due to the size of the numerical model for the solution, parallel processing offered by ANSYS FE code has been utilized, employing all four available cores. Despite the considerable computational power available, the iteration solution time was about 45 min.

sec.title: Sub-Modeling Technique and Failure Analysis Module Application
sec.p:
For all the areas around the bolt holes of the composite panels, local refined FE models are developed for the application of sub-modeling technique. At the sub-models, one SOLID185 element per layer of composite material is used. Sub-models are subsequently solved by applying the boundary displacements computed by the global-model analysis. Next, failure analysis module is applied and LED and SAD indices are calculated. An example of typical damage patterns (for the different failure modes), as predicted by the application of the failure analysis module combined with sub-modeling technique, is presented in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Typical predicted failures at a sub-model: (a) matrix cracking in tension, (b) matrix cracking in compression, (c) fiber failure in tension, (d) fiber–matrix shear-out, (e) delamination in tension, and (f) delamination in compression.

It should be emphasized that, although during the first iteration the stress and failure analysis as well as material property degradation modules of the PDM are executed for all sub-areas, for the subsequent iterations, the process is limited only to critical sub-areas, as selected by the application of the proposed SAD indices and described in detail in the following section. Additionally, the utilization of LED indices leads to the limitation of the layers/elements within each analyzed sub-model, for which failure analysis checks are performed.

sec.title: Damage Indices Application
sec.p: At the first iteration of the PDM application, during the failure analysis module, LED and SAD indices are calculated for each sub-model and the elements it comprises. At each subsequent iteration, the respective LED and SAD indices are effortlessly assessed according to Equations (5)–(8). The calculated values of the indices are compared to the respective threshold values, in order for the critical sub-areas and layers/elements to be distinguished from the noncritical ones, with respect to the probability of failure initiation. For this application, the threshold values of the damage indices considered are:

The lower value of dcr, compared to Dcr, reflects the higher possibility that the stress level at a layer/element is significantly affected by the damage evolution at neighboring layers/elements than the respective effect between adjacent sub-areas. Such severe stress interactions lead to inaccurate calculation of damage indices by Equations (5)–(8), as the assumption on which they are based (i.e. local stresses are proportional to the externally applied load), is no longer valid. In general, choosing higher values for Dcr and dcr, allows reduced computational cost, but renders the analysis procedure less conservative and vice versa.

A typical pattern of critical sub-areas, as defined by the application of SAD indices for the case of the generic shear joint PDM analysis, is shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Predicted critical (red) and noncritical (green) sub-areas of the shear joint (20% of the maximum load).

sec.title: Effect of Developed Failures on the Distribution of Transferred Loads
sec.p:
By exploiting the advantages of the modified PDM, it became possible to assess the effect of the composite material developed failures on the shear joint behavior, which otherwise would be impossible. As a benchmark, the distribution of forces transferred from the joint bolts to the composite plates, has been chosen. To this goal, the whole numerical model has been solved again without the application of the PDM methodology. In Figure 10, bolt-transferred forces for the two cases (with and without the application of the modified PDM) are presented and compared. For reference reasons bolts and respective sub-areas have been numbered according to their location in the joint. It is clear that the consideration of failure development in the composite material, leads to significant force redistribution, specially at the areas of high load transfer that obviously exhibit the major material damages. Figure 10.
Effect of local material failures on the bolt-transferred forces distribution.

sec.title: Gain in the Computational Cost from the Application of the Modified PDM
sec.p: In general, sub-modeling methodology is considered to be efficient, with respect to computational cost, for handling stress-analysis problems, where there is a need for accurate results at specific areas of the structure. Moreover, as accurate stress field calculation at layer level is required for the application of the failure analysis module of the conventional PDM methodology, dense discretization at the structure’s FE model is necessary. In cases of large-scale structures, such as the generic shear joint, the above requirement would lead to extremely large numerical models that demand significant computational effort in order to be solved. Therefore, the application of the PDM methodology in cases of large-scale structures would not be feasible without the advantages offered by the sub-modeling technique.

Additionally, the application of damage indices has resulted in a significant saving of computational cost by the reduction of the number of sub-regions and layers/elements checked for failure occurrence at each step load. In the diagram of Figure 11, the number of sub-areas to which sub-modeling and damage failure analysis had to be performed is shown as a function of load step, with and without the application of SAD indices. Similarly, in the diagram of Figure 12, the number of elements in the numerical model for which damage analysis has to be performed at each load step, with and without the application of LED indices, is presented. Figure 11.
Number of analyzed sub-areas as a function of load step, with and without the application of SAD index. Figure 12.
Number of analyzed elements with and without the application of LED indices.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this study, proper modifications are introduced in the classic PDM methodology in order to be efficiently applied for the prediction of damage initiation and progression at large-scale composite structures. The sub-modeling technique principles are exploited for the efficient stress analysis. Additionally, two damage indices are introduced that characterize the sub-areas and layers/elements of the structure’s FE model according to the criticality for failure initiation and lead to a selection of the noncritical sub-areas and layers/elements, for which stress and failure analysis may be omitted.

The proposed modification made feasible the application of the PDM methodology in the case of the generic shear joint. From the PDM analysis of the generic shear joint, the following conclusions may be drawn:
There is a significant redistribution of transferred forces at the joint, when local failures are taken into account, compared to the case when no failures are considered. This leads to the conclusion that damage evolution is crucial for the accurate prediction of large-scale structural behavior, something that would be impractical without the application of the proposed modified PDM methodology.
The implementation of the proposed damage indices leads to the significant reduction of computational effort required for the application of PDM methodology in the analysis of the generic shear joint, thus demonstrating their efficiency in cases of large-scale structures.
